unnormalised: The Delhi Jal Board (DJB) has announced a revised tariff structure for water bills effective 01/07/2024. According to the new regulations, households consuming up to 20,000 liters of water per month will continue to receive free water. However, consumers exceeding this limit will face significantly higher charges, starting at Rs. 276.54 for the next slab. This revision aims to encourage responsible water usage among Delhi residents amid growing concerns over water scarcity.
normalised: The Delhi Jal Board (D-J-B) has announced a revised tariff structure for water bills effective first july two thousand and twenty four. According to the new regulations, households consuming up to twenty thousand liters of water per month will continue to receive free water. However, consumers exceeding this limit will face significantly higher charges, starting at rupees two hundred and seventy six point five four for the next slab. This revision aims to encourage responsible water usage among Delhi residents amid growing concerns over water scarcity.

unnormalised: For households consuming between 20,001 and 30,000 liters, the tariff has been increased by 15%, while those using between 30,001 and 40,000 liters will see a rise of 25%. Consumption above 40,000 liters will be charged at the highest rate of Rs. 493.15. The DJB clarified that these changes are necessary to offset rising operational costs and ensure equitable distribution of water resources, urging citizens to conserve water and pay their bills promptly to avoid penalties. Payments can be made online via the DJB website or at designated payment centers.
normalised: For households consuming between twenty thousand and one and thirty thousand liters, the tariff has been increased by fifteen percent, while those using between thirty thousand and one and forty thousand liters will see a rise of twenty five percent. Consumption above forty thousand liters will be charged at the highest rate of rupees four hundred and ninety three point one five. The D-J-B clarified that these changes are necessary to offset rising operational costs and ensure equitable distribution of water resources, urging citizens to conserve water and pay their bills promptly to avoid penalties. Payments can be made online via the D-J-B website or at designated payment centers.

unnormalised: The new tariff structure is expected to impact approximately 30% of Delhi households. The move has sparked mixed reactions, with some residents expressing concerns over the increased financial burden, while others support the measure as a necessary step towards water conservation. The DJB maintains that the revised rates are still subsidized compared to other metropolitan cities and encourages consumers to monitor their water consumption closely to stay within the free usage limit. They also announced a helpline number, 1916, for any queries related to billing and water supply.
